user_request: Write a villanelle about the loss of time.
final_poem:
The clock said loss is just a word, but hours
peeled from me like rinds off oranges in March.
I kept rearranging what I had left stored.

A glass of water on the nightstand
kept cooling to that temperature of yours—
the one where bodies nearly make their match.
But time, the gross old hag who takes her shawl

stole every morning before it was arrayed,
each filament of light she pulled like taffee
and sold me back to myself as something small.

The glass kept shrinking on its coaster.
My hands performed their tasks with such good will—
a window washed, a cello wiped clean—               (refrain)

but somewhere underneath the kitchen faucet,
a thread of absent minutes ran to sill.

I can't recall what you looked like at the start.
The glass keeps cooling. March keeps doing that.
A body left alone grows almost still.              (refrain)

What I call loss, time calls simply fact:
the bath towel folded into nothing flat
and stacked with others in its gray damp hold.   (refrain)
